choices.text: AFP
β- hCG
Estriol
Inhibin-B

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in quadruple test for antenatal detection of Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibin -B

 

Explanation:

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.
  • Inhibin A is a component of quadruple. Not Inhibin B

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A (AFP), Option B (beta hCG) and Option C (Estriol) are all components of the Quadruple marker

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are 2nd trimester biochemical screening tests for Down Syndrome and are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

Ref: Page no 284, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

questions.solution:
Ans. A) High HCG, low ue3, low AFP

 

Explanation:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are 2nd trimester biochemical screening tests for Down Syndrome and are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

questions.text: A couple presents in the 1st trimester and ask about Down syndrome screening. They are very concerned as a relative in the family has Down syndrome. What is the ideal time for doing a Quadruple test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 15 – 18 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Both the triple and the quadruple marker are performed between 15 – 21 weeks gestation but exact gestational age ranges vary according to laboratories.

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are 2nd trimester biochemical screening tests for Down Syndrome and are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

choices.text: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies
Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova
Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome
Testing of maternal tissue

questions.text: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:

  • Introduced in 2011
  • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were
    • Age ≥ 35 y
    • A positive 1st /2nd trimester analyte-based screening test
    • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
    • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
    • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.
  • Done after 9 – 10 weeks
  • Results in 7 – 10 days
  • 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome
  • Limitations:
    • Cost
    • The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect:
      • Placental mosaicism
      • Early demise of an aneuploid twin
      • Maternal mosaicism
      • Occult maternal malignancy
      • Limited role in multiple pregnancy
      • In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic method for fetal chromosomal anomalies. It is preferably done after 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Option B. Preconceptional gene testing for an ova: There is no such thing; however preimplantation genetic testing can be done of an embryo in IVF, prior to embryo transfer.
  • Option D. Testing of maternal tissue: This is not a test for screening or diagnosis of Down syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:

  • Introduced in 2011
  • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were
    • Age ≥ 35 y
    • A positive 1st /2nd trimester analyte-based screening test
    • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
    • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
    • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.
  • Done after 9 – 10 weeks
  • Results in 7 – 10 days
  • 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome
  • Limitations:
    • Cost
    • The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect:
      • Placental mosaicism
      • Early demise of an aneuploid twin
      • Maternal mosaicism
      • Occult maternal malignancy
    • Limited role in multiple pregnancy
    • In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

 

Ref: Page No 284, 285; William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Trisomy 21
Trisomy 18
Turner Syndrome
Klinefelter Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klinefelter Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options

 

  • Option A and B. Prenatal aneuploidy screening is primarily used to detect Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). It can also detect Trisomy 18 (Edward) and Trisomy 13 (Patau).
  • Option C. Turner Syndrome:
    • Nuchal Translucency (NT) is used in prenatal aneuploidy screening and is increased in several conditions other than Down syndrome, and this includes Turner’s syndrome.
    • Turner syndrome also has several other ultrasound features like
      • Cystic hygroma
      • Non-immune fetal hydrops
      • Cardiac anomalies (mostly compromising the left outflow tract - CoA, HLHS, bicuspid aortic valve)
      • Renal anomalies
      • Pleural effusions
      • Brachycephaly
      • IUGR
  • Option D. Klinefelter’s syndrome does not have any significant USG finding especially in the 1st and 2nd trimesters and hence potentially can be easily missed on prenatal screening.

 

Ref: Page No 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: It is the most commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure
Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes
Blood-tinged amniotic fluid is seen in transplacental passage of the needle
Procedure related loss rate is 1 -2% when performed by an experienced provider

questions.text: All are true regarding amniocentesis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Procedure related loss rate is 1-2 % when performed by an experienced provider

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all Options:

 

  • Option A. Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure.
  • Option B. Chromosomal microarray can be performed on uncultured amniocytes: Following amniocentesis, analysis can be done using
  1. Chromosomal microarray (CMA) – to assess copy number gains or losses: can be performed directly on uncultured amniocytes
  2. Karyotype analysis for aneuploidy: requires cultures amniocytes
  3. FISH to identify gain or loss of specific chromosomes.
  • Option C. Anterior placentation seen in 60% and blood-tinged fluid is more frequent if there is transplacental passage of the needle.
  • Option D.
    • Procedure related loss: 0.1 – 0.3 % when performed by an experienced provider.
    • Early amniocentesis (11-14 weeks): significant higher rate of procedure related complications; like clubfoot, amnionic fluid leakage and fetal loss. Not done anymore.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure.
  • Indications for amniocentesis include:
    • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders
    • Diagnosis of Congenital infection
    • Evaluation of anemia in Rh alloimmunization
    • Determination of Fetal lung maturity
  • Following amniocentesis, analysis can be done using
  1. Chromosomal microarray (CMA) – to assess copy number gains or losses: can be performed directly on uncultured amniocytes
  2. Karyotype analysis for aneuploidy: requires cultures amniocytes
  3. FISH to identify gain or loss of specific chromosomes.
  • Procedure:
    • Ultrasound guided
    • Done between 15- 20weeks
    • Anterior placentation seen in 60% and blood-tinged fluid is more frequent if there is transplacental passage of the needle.
    • For fetal karyotype, about 20 -30 ml withdrawn.
  • Procedure related loss: 0.1 – 0.3 % when performed by an experienced provider.
  • Early amniocentesis (11-14 weeks): significant higher rate of procedure related complications; like clubfoot, amnionic fluid leakage and fetal loss. Not done anymore.

   

Ref: Page No 292, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: High cost
Low Detection Rate
Low detection of free DNA in 5% of samples
Limited role in multiple pregnancy

questions.text: A couple opts for Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) for Down syndrome screening. Which is NOT a drawback of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Detection Rate

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A. NIPT is a costly test
  • Option B. NIPT is a screening test for Down syndrome with the highest detection rate (99%)
  • Option C. In 5% of samples, the fetal fraction of DNA may be low so it may not be possible to do the test
  • Option D. NIPT has a limited role in multiple pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:

 

  • Introduced in 2011
  • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were
    • Age ≥ 35 y
    • A positive 1st /2nd trimester analyte-based screening test
    • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
    • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
    • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.
  • Done after 9 – 10 weeks
  • Results in 7 – 10 days
  • 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome
  • Limitations:
    • Cost
    • The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect:
      • Placental mosaicism
      • Early demise of an aneuploid twin
      • Maternal mosaicism
      • Occult maternal malignancy
    • Limited role in multiple pregnancy
    • In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

 

Ref: Page No 284, 285; William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: The risk of a woman carrying a Down syndrome baby is about 1 in 70 at 40 years
Ultrasound features of Down syndrome at 11 – 14 weeks include increased NT and an absent nasal bone
Combined test includes an  NT measurement and the dual marker
Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

questions.text: All are true regarding prenatal Down syndrome screening except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options

 

  • Option A. The risk of Down syndrome increases with maternal age. At the age of 40y, the risk os about 1 in 70
  • Option B. At 11-14 weeks, ultrasound features of Down syndrome include
    • An increased nuchal translucency
    • An absent nasal bone
    • Tricuspid regurgitation
    • An abnormal flow in the ductus venosus
  • Option C. Combined test refers to a combination of the NT and Dual marker
  • Option D. An ultrasound at 18-20 weeks will detect upto 70% of Down syndrome babies. Hence this option is correct

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of Down Syndrome:
  • Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome); is the most common non-lethal trisomy
  • Background risk is based on age (At 25 y: 1 in 5000, 30 y: 1 in 1000, 33 y: 1 in 500, 35 y: 1 in 250, 40 y: 1 in 70, 45 y: 1 in 20)
  • Ultrasound at 11 – 14 weeks: Features of Down Syndrome include:
    • Increased NT
    • Absent nasal bone
    • Abnormal flow in the Ductus venosus
    • Tricuspid Regurgitation
  • 1st trimester screening for Down Syndrome includes the Dual marker and the NT.
  • Detection rate for Down Syndrome by a 2nd trimester ultrasound is 70%

 

Ref: Page no 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha Feto Protein
Beta hCG
Inhibin A
PAPP-A

questions.text: All are serum analytes used in prenatal screening for Down Syndrome in the 2nd trimester except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PAPP-A

 

Explanation:

 

  • Serum analytes used in prenatal screening of Down syndrome are:
    • 1st trimester (11 – 14 weeks): Dual marker: β hCG (↑) and PAPP-A (↓)
    • 2nd trimester (15 – 21 weeks):
      • Triple marker: β hCG (↑), unconjugated Estriol uE3 (↓) and Maternal serum Alpha fetoprotein – MSAFP (↓)
      • Quadruple marker: β hCG (↑), Inhibin – A (↑), unconjugated Estriol uE3 (↓) and Maternal serum Alpha fetoprotein – MSAFP (↓)

 

Thus, Option D) PAPP-A is not used in the second trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum analytes used in prenatal screening of Down syndrome are:
    • 1st trimester (11 – 14 weeks): Dual marker: β hCG (↑) and PAPP-A (↓)
    • 2nd trimester (15 – 21 weeks):
      • Triple marker: β hCG (↑), unconjugated Estriol uE3 (↓) and Maternal serum Alpha fetoprotein – MSAFP (↓)
      • Quadruple marker: β hCG (↑), Inhibin – A (↑), unconjugated Estriol uE3 (↓) and Maternal serum Alpha fetoprotein – MSAFP (↓)

 

Ref: Page no 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: The following are prenatal diagnostic tests except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell free DNA

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Prenatal Diagnostic techniques include:
  2. Amniocentesis (including early amniocentesis)
  3. Chorionic Villous sampling
  4. Cordocentesis (aka Percutaneous umbilical vein sampling or fetal blood sampling)
  5. Cell free DNA or NIPT is a prenatal SCREENING test (Not a diagnostic test).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prenatal Diagnostic techniques include:

 

  • Amniocentesis (including early amniocentesis)
  • Chorionic Villous sampling
  • Cordocentesis (aka Percutaneous umbilical vein sampling or fetal blood sampling)

 

Page no 292, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 10 – 13 weeks
10 weeks 6 days – 13 weeks 6 days
12 – 14 weeks
11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days

questions.text: The image below shows the Nuchal translucency (NT) on Ultrasound. A high NT is associated with fetal aneuploidies and poor perinatal outcome. At what gestational period is the NT measured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  • Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • If NT increased, risk for
    • Fetal aneuploidy
    • Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  • Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  2. Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  3. If NT increased, risk for
    1. Fetal aneuploidy
    2. Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  4. Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)
  5. Criteria to measure the NT
    1. CRL between 45 – 84 mm
    2. Fetus in mid sagittal plane
    3. Fetus in neutral position
    4. Image must be magnified
    5. Widest space should be measured
    6. The amnion must be seen separately
    7. The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space

 

 

  1. NT alone of used: 65% detection rate for Down Syndrome
  2. Combined test: NT + Dual marker (beta hCG + PAPP-A): 80% Detection rate
  3. NT > 3 mm/ > 99th percentile: Significant

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid
Measurement of cystic hygroma
Nuchal fold thickness
Nuchal translucency

questions.text: The below ultrasound done at 12 weeks shows what measurement being taken?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuchal Translucency

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A: Deepest pocket of amniotic fluid: This measurement is used to determine the amniotic fluid volume. A normal DVP is 2-8 cm
  • Option B: Measurement of cystic hygroma: A cystic hygroma is a large neck swelling seen in the fetus and is seen in Turner syndrome fetuses
  • Option C: Nuchal fold thickness: This is a measurement taken at the level 2 scan and is seen in various anomalies and chromosomal aneuploidies
  • Option D: The measurement shown here is the nuchal translucency. An increased NT is a marker of fetal aneuploidies and various fetal structural anomalies

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  1. Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  2. Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  3. If NT increased, risk for
    • Fetal aneuploidy
    • Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  • Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)
  • Criteria to measure the NT
    • CRL between 45 – 84 mm
    • Fetus in mid sagittal plane
    • Fetus in neutral position
    • Image must be magnified
    • Widest space should be measured
    • The amnion must be seen separately
    • The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space

 

 

  1. NT alone of used: 65% detection rate for Down Syndrome
  2. Combined test: NT + Dual marker (beta hCG + PAPP-A): 80% Detection rate
  3. NT > 3 mm/ > 99th percentile: Significant

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Amniocentesis
Chorionic Villous Sampling
Percutaneous Umbilical Vein Sampling
Measuring cell free DNA

questions.text: What is this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniocentesis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows an amniocentesis. Amniocentesis is aspiration of the amniotic fluid for therapeutic or diagnostic procedures

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Chorionic villous sampling is as shown below. It is a procedure done between 10-13 weeks for diagnosis of chromosomal and genetic abnormalities

 

  • Option C: Percutaneous blood sampling or cordocentesis: This is as shown in the image below and is aspiration of blood from the umbilical vein for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. It can be done > 18 weeks.

 

 

  • Option D: Measuring cell free DNA: This is a screening test for Down syndrome wherein a maternal blood sample is taken and fetal DNA is extracted.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amniocentesis:

 

  • Most Commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure
  • Done at 15 – 20 weeks for prenatal diagnosis but can be done later also
  • Indications:
    • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders (prenatal diagnosis)
    • Diagnosis of congenital infections
    • Rh alloimmunization (measurement of amniotic fluid bilirubin to determine severity of fetal anemia)
    • Assessment of fetal lung maturity (Lecithin/ Sphingomyelin ratio and measurement of amniotic fluid phosphatidyl glycerol in the amniotic fluid)
  • Technique:
    • 20 – 22 -gauge spinal needle
    • Ultrasound guidance
    • Needle inserted into amniotic fluid pocket
    • Avoid umbilical cord, fetal parts
    • Aspirate 10 – 20 ml if sending for fetal karyotype/FISH or chromosomal microarray
    • Discard initial 1-2 ml (may be contamination with maternal blood)
    • If Rh D negative: and unsensitized: Give Anti-D
  • Complications:
    • Procedure related loss: 0.1-0.3%
    • Amniotic fluid leakage
    • Vaginal spotting
  • Early amniocentesis
    • 11- 14 weeks
    • Higher procedure related loss, increased incidence of talipes equinovarus (clubfoot)
    • Not done now

 

Ref: Page No 291, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Artificial rupture of membranes
Chorionic villous sampling
Cordocentesis
Early amniocentesis

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorionic Villous Sampling

 

Explanation:

 

This is an image showing Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS). This is a procedure done between 10 – 13 weeks wherein chorionic villi obtained via transabdominal or transcervical route for diagnosis of fetal chromosomal or genetic abnormalities

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artificial Rupture of membranes (ARM): is a procedure as shown below. In this, the membranes are ruptured for induction of labor or augmentation of labor

 

 

  • Option C. Cordocentesis: This is as shown in the image below and is aspiration of blood from the umbilical vein for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. It can be done > 18 weeks.

 

  • Indications:
    • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders (prenatal diagnosis)
    • Diagnosis of congenital infections
    • Rh alloimmunization (measurement of amniotic fluid bilirubin to determine severity of fetal anemia)
    • Assessment of fetal lung maturity (Lecithin/ Sphingomyelin ratio and measurement of amniotic fluid phosphatidyl glycerol in the amniotic fluid)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorionic Villous sampling is done between 10-13 weeks wherein chorionic villi obtained via transabdominal or transcervical route for diagnosis of fetal chromosomal or genetic abnormalities

 

  • Advantage: do not have to wait till 15 weeks for amniocentesis, results quicker
  • Complications
    • Overall loss rate: higher than amniocentesis because of background losses
    • Procedure related loss: same as amniocentesis (0.1 -0.3%)
    • If done < 7 weeks: limb reduction defects & oro mandibular defects
    • Vaginal spotting

 

Ref: Page no 293, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetus with Down syndrome
Fetus with renal anomaly
Fetus with cystic hygroma
Fetus with intestinal obstruction

questions.text: Maternal serum AFP is increased in all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetus with Down Syndrome

 

In mothers with Down Syndrome fetuses, MSAFP is decreased

 

Other Options:

 

Fetal renal anomalies, cystic hygromas and GI anomalies are associated with an increases MSAFP

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Conditions associated with an increased MSAFP

 

  • Neural tube defect
  • Gastroschisis, Omphalocele
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction
  • Liver necrosis
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cloacal dystrophy
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma

 

Maternal Conditions associated with an increased MSAFP:

 

  • Underestimated maternal age
  • Placental abruption
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Fetal growth restriction

 

Conditions associated with a decreased MSAFP

 

  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Trisomy 21
  • GTD
  • Fetal death
  • Overestimated gestational age

 

Ref: page no 283, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: ↑βhCG, ↑MSAFP, ↑uE3
↓βhCG, ↑MSAFP ↑uE3
↑βhCG, ↓MSAFP ↓uE3
↓βhCG, ↓MSAFP, ↓uE3

questions.text: In Edwards syndrome, the triple marker will show the following report:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ↓βhCG, ↓MSAFP, ↓uE3

 

Explanation:

 

Both the triple and the quadruple marker are performed between 15 – 21 weeks gestation but exact gestational age ranges vary according to laboratories.

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

 

Ref: Page no 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Amniocentesis
Cell free DNA
Integrated test
Quadruple test

questions.text: A 37 y primigravida is 8 weeks pregnant. She is worried about the risk of her having a baby with Down syndrome as she read that increased age is associated with a higher risk. She has also read that screening can be done once she is pregnant. She wants to opt for a test that has the highest detection rate. What screening test would you recommend?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell free DNA

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cell free DNA (NIPT) has the highest detection rate amongst all screening tests (99%)

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test
  • Option C. Integrated test: This has a detection rate of about 95%
  • Option D. Quadruple marker: This has a detection rate of 80%

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page No 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: It is a component of the dual marker
It’s concentration in fetal plasma is 50000 times that in maternal plasma
It is increased in defects in fetal integument
Using an upper limit of MSAFP > 2.5 MoM, the detection rate of anencephaly is 90%

questions.text: False statement regarding MSAFP is:
questions.solution:
Ans: A) It is a component of the dual marker

 

Explanation:

 

  • Dual marker consists of βhCG and PAPP-A

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. The concentration of MSAFP in fetal plasma is 50000 times greater than in maternal plasma
  • Option C. It is increased in defect s in fetal integument like open neural tube defects (NTD’s) and defects of ventral wall (Gastroschisis and omphalocele)
  • Option D. Using an upper limit of MSAFP > 2.5 MoM, the detection rate of anencephaly is 90%

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MSAFP:
    • Usually measured between 15 – 20 weeks
    • It is increased in defects of fetal integument like open neural tube defects (NTD’s) and defects of ventral wall (Gastroschisis and omphalocele)
    • It is the major protein in the fetal plasma
    • Concentration is 50000 times that in maternal serum
    • Using an MSAFP of > 2.5 MoM as the upper limit of normal, the NTD detection rate is 90% for anencephaly and 80% for spina bifida.

 

Ref: page no 283, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: PAPP-A
PlGF
S Eng
VEGF

questions.text: The following biochemical predictors are decreased in a woman at high risk of developing preeclampsia except:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. S Eng

 

Explanation:

 

  • S eng (soluble endoglin) is increased in women at risk of developing preeclampsia

 

Other Options:

 

  • PAPP-A, PlGF and VEGF: All are decreased in women at risk of developing preeclampsia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Screening of preeclampsia is based on history (Risk factors), Mean arterial pressure, Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks and biochemical factors.

 

Risk Factors

 

 

Other predictors of preeclampsia:

 

  • Biophysical markers: Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11 – 14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester).
  • Biochemical markers:

 

 

Women at high risk of developing pre-eclampsia based on these parameters should be started on Low dose aspirin 75-150 mg before 16 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 726, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

Ans. C) Multigravida

choices.text: Down Syndrome
Gestational Diabetes
Placenta previa
Preeclampsia

questions.text: A raised uterine pulsatility index at 11-14 weeks on uterine artery doppler is a predictor for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine artery blood flow is estimated to rise from 50ml/min early in gestation to 500-700 ml/ min by term
  • Doppler waveform of the uterine artery shows high diastolic flow velocity and markedly turbulent flow.
  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Thus, option D) Pre-eclampsia is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A raised uterine PI is not related to gestational diabetes, Down syndrome or placenta previa

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching  on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Ref: Page no 214, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 8-10 weeks
12-13 weeks
18-20 weeks
20-22 weeks

questions.text: Nuchal translucency for anomaly scan on USG is usually detected at which week of gestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 12-13 weeks

 

Explanation

 

  • Nuchal Translucency is done between 11 – 14 weeks (more exactly 11 -13weeks 6 days)
  • The best option in these choices is therefore B (12 – 13 weeks)
  • It is a component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  • Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • If NT increased, risk for
    • Fetal aneuploidy
    • Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nuchal Translucency is a parameter seen on ultrasound done between 11 – 14 weeks
  • An increased value is seen in Down syndrome, ither chromosomal aneuploidies and in several fetal structural abnormalities

 

Ref: Page 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Down syndrome
Gastroschisis
Gestational diabetes
Intra uterine death

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD for her first visit at 16 weeks. She opts for the triple screen. Her report shows an elevated maternal serum AFP level. An elevated maternal serum AFP level puts her at an increased risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastroschisis

 

  • Gastroschisis is associated with an increased maternal serum AFP

 

Other Options:

 

  • Down syndrome, gestational diabetes and IUD are associated with decreased maternal serum AFP

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Conditions associated with an increased MSAFP

 

  • Neural tube defect
  • Gastroschisis, Omphalocele
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction
  • Liver necrosis
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cloacal dystrophy
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma

 

Maternal conditions associated with an increased MSAFP:

 

  • Underestimated maternal age
  • Placental abruption
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Fetal growth restriction

 

Conditions associated with a decreased MSAFP

 

  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Trisomy 21
  • GTD
  • Fetal death
  • Overestimated gestational age

 

Ref: Page no 284, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening
Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT)
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
Nuchal translucency ultrasound

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her first trimester presents for prenatal care. She inquires about prenatal screening for chromosomal abnormalities. What is the most appropriate initial screening test for assessing chromosomal abnormalities in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuchal translucency ultrasound

 

Explanation: Nuchal translucency ultrasound, performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, is the most appropriate initial screening test for assessing chromosomal abnormalities in the first trimester. It measures the thickness of the nuchal fold and, when combined with maternal age, can estimate the risk of conditions like Down syndrome.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A: AFP is usually done at16-18 weeks for detecting neural tube defects in the fetus as it is high in such patients.
  • Option B: Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) or cell free DNA is a screening test with a very high detection rate for fetal genetic abnormalities. It can be done after 9 weeks of pregnancy. However, it is usually not prescribed as an initial test due to its expense. In women who are elderly (> 35y) or other risk factors, it can be offered as a preliminary test
  • Option C: Chorionic villous sampling: This is a diagnostic test for fetal genetic abnormalities done between 11-13 weeks.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The initial tests prescribed in a low risk pregnant woman for screening for chromosomal abnormalities include
    • Nuchal translucency (11-14 weeks)
    • Dual marker (βhCG and PAPP-A)
    • Combined marker (NT + Dual marker)
    • NIPT after 9 weeks (Can be offered as an initial test but is expensive so usually offered in elderly mothers or any other risk factor)

 

Ref: Page no 281, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening
Amniocentesis
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is concerned about the risk of chromosomal abnormalities due to her advanced maternal age. Which of the following prenatal screening tests is specifically recommended for women aged 35 and older?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT)

 

Explanation: Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is specifically recommended for women aged 35 and older and is a highly accurate screening test for chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome. It involves a simple blood test that analyzes cell-free fetal DNA in the mother's bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: AFP is for detecting neural tube defects where it is found to be raised. Done between 16-18 weeks
  • Option B & Option C: Amniocentesis and CVS are diagnostic tests and are advised if a screening test is positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial tests prescribed in a low risk pregnant woman for screening for chromosomal abnormalities include

 

  • Nuchal translucency (11-14 weeks)
  • Dual marker (βhCG and PAPP-A)
  • Combined marker (NT + Dual marker)
  • NIPT after 9 weeks (Can be offered as an initial test but is expensive so usually offered in elderly mothers or any other risk factor)

 

Ref: Page no , William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening
Nuchal translucency ultrasound
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
Amniocentesis

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is at her second trimester prenatal visit. She inquires about screening for neural tube defects. Which prenatal screening test is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

 

Explanation: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Nuchal Translucency (NT): Done at 11-14 weeks as screening for Down syndrome. It is increased in fetuses with Down syndrome and also increased in other chromosomal abnormalities and congenital abnormalities like cardiac diseases.
  • Option C & Option D: CVS and Amniocentesis are diagnostic techniques for detecting chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Ref: Page no 273, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT)
Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis
Amniocentesis

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is concerned about her risk of carrying a baby with a genetic disorder due to a family history of cystic fibrosis. What prenatal screening test should be offered to assess the risk of cystic fibrosis in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carrier screening for cystic fibrosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • Cystic Fibrosis is caused due to a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7 and affects chloride channels.
  • To assess the risk of carrying a baby with cystic fibrosis, carrier screening for cystic fibrosis is appropriate.
  • This test analyzes the parents' carrier status for the cystic fibrosis gene mutations and provides information about the risk of having an affected child.
  • If both parents are carriers, invasive tests such as CVS and amniocentesis should be offered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance and hence only if both partners are carriers, is diagnostic testing (CVS or amniocentesis) warranted

 

Ref: Page no 289, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening and nuchal translucency ultrasound
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT)
Amniocentesis and nuchal translucency ultrasound
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with a family history of a genetic disorder is considering invasive prenatal testing. What are the two common invasive prenatal diagnostic tests that can provide definitive information about chromosomal or genetic abnormalities in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis

 

Explanation: Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis are the two common invasive prenatal diagnostic tests that can provide definitive information about chromosomal or genetic abnormalities in the fetus. These tests involve the direct sampling of fetal tissue (CVS samples the placenta, and amniocentesis samples amniotic fluid) and can diagnose various genetic conditions.

 

Prenatal Diagnostic Tests:

 

  1. Amniocentesis
  2. Chorionic Villous Sampling
  3. Fetal blood sampling/ Cordocentesis/ Percutaneous Umbilical Vein Sampling

 

1. Amniocentesis:

 

 

  • Most Commonly performed prenatal diagnostic procedure
  • Done at 15 – 20 weeks for prenatal diagnosis but can be done later also
  • Indications:
    • Diagnosis of fetal genetic disorders (prenatal diagnosis)
    • Diagnosis of congenital infections
    • Rh alloimmunization (measurement of amniotic fluid bilirubin to determine severity of fetal anemia
    • Assessment of fetal lung maturity (Lecithin/ Sphingomyelin ratio and measurement of amniotic fluid phosphatidyl glycerol in the amniotic fluid)
       
  • Complications:
    • Procedure related loss: 0.1-0.3%
    • Amniotic fluid leakage
    • Vaginal spotting

 

2. Chorionic Villous Sampling

 

 

  • Done at 10 – 13 weeks
  • Chorionic villi obtained via transabdominal or transcervical route
  • Advantage: do not have to wait till 15 weeks for amniocentesis, results quicker
  • Complications
    • Overall loss rate: higher than amniocentesis because of background losses
    • Procedure related loss: same as amniocentesis (0.1 -0.3%)
    • If done < 7 weeks: limb reduction defects & oro mandibular defects
    • Vaginal spotting

 

Other options:

 

  • AFP is a noninvasive test (blood sample) for detection of neural tube defects
  • Nuchal translucency is a screening test for Down syndrome done by ultrasound
  • NIPT is cell free DNA. It is a screening test done after 9 weeks for fetal chromosomal abnormalities

 

Educational Objective: Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis are the two common invasive prenatal diagnostic tests that can provide definitive information about chromosomal or genetic abnormalities in the fetus. These tests involve the direct sampling of fetal tissue (CVS samples the placenta, and amniocentesis samples amniotic fluid) and can diagnose various genetic conditions.

 

Ref: Page no 293, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition
